I have a female friend who's a (PhD) math professor at a university in the
Atlanta area, and she has prosopagnosia. She also has another condition that is closely associated with face blindness: namely, Asperger's.

Though this article didn't mention it, a disproportionate number of people with Asperger's also have prosopagnosia, And, to add to the mix, a disproportionate number of mathematicians have Asperger's.

So, there you have it, a triangle: Prosopagnosia Asperger's Mathematical talent .

How do I know all this? I have Asperger's myself and know several Aspies with prosopagnosia (including the aforementioned math professor). And, my son, who is working on his PhD in theoretical math at MIT, also has Asperger's. (In fact, here in the Boston area, we call MIT "Asperger's Central.") Fortunately, neither my son nor I have prosopagnosia. (So, no excuses for us when we fail to remember people.)

Dates in 2013 and 1963 fell on the same days of the week, so 1963 had a late Thanksgiving also. My collector's edition of The New York World-Telegram and Sun from Nov. 22, 1963 (still available to anyone who collects JFK memorabilia) includes little space-fillers urging shoppers to do their Christmas shopping in November. They even survived to the paper's final edition (which was late enough to be one of the only east coast papers that announced the President's death in an edition dated 11/22). I suspect the editors were too busy with the Top Story to take out silliness like the little space-fillers and the TV listings (the Jack Paar show was supposed to feature Cassius Clay and Liberace).

So vexing.... I've been a loyal Yahoo Mail user for over a decade (opting for the $20/year service for a few extras). The outages are a serious concern, but the full-scale redesign alluded to in the article is what has me ready to pack my bags and leave the site altogether. I'll add my voice to the loud chorus of Yahoo Mail users who have lamented the recent switch to a gmail look-alike (and a poor one at that) that ditched some of the most useful features (Tabs, and an intuitive display).

Between the two onerous choices of 1) staying with the current Yahoo Mail and its unpleasant format and lack of consistency and 2) leaving, but severing my online identity with that address both for my many frequent and less frequent contacts, and the services (e.g. Flickr) associated with my Yahoo account, I'll stick grudgingly with option 1, but there's only so much nonsense and frustration I can take before it's Hello, Gmail. Come on, Yahoo, listen to your customers -- or are those feedback forums just an empty exercise for us all?

Actually, we have entered the era of peak oil, and fracking is the proof. Anyone who actually read the peak oil books — "The Party's Over," etc. — understands that "peak oil" doesn't mean that we world will run of oil in the immediate future.

It means that we have passed the peak in the accessibility of oil that yields a high energy returned on energy invested ratio (EROEI). We can no longer simply drill a hole in the ground and tap into huge oil reservoirs. Instead, we will be forced to spend more and more energy going after smaller and smaller pockets of fossil fuels, and employing more risky and expensive technologies such as deep sea drilling in the process.

One of my takeaways from this series is that places like Auburn House act as collecting points for cascading disaster. In the past, it was the huge, multi-story public housing projects of despair that got attention for their massive failure. Many cities have torn down those projects, finally concluding that what was intended as a act of kindness was actually the opposite.

Where I live, Montgomery County, Maryland, one of the richest counties in the nation, a relatively enlightened form of housing assistance is offered. Lower cost housing is dispersed among higher cost units so that those on assistance are not placed in islands of poverty and family breakdown. The surrounding middle class areas are not significantly altered. It seems to be working fairly well.

A key issue in a massive city like New York is the availability of decent housing at non-millionaire pricing. Perhaps the builders who put up the 50 story towers in Manhattan could be required to build, and operate, a set number of affordable units in other areas of the city in exchange for the right to make millions on office towers of glass and steel.

I would favor a three to five yr. program whereby the family would be given money, on a declining scale, to establish themselves economically. Some people, further, might need to consider moving because "making it", or even just getting by, in a complex, educated society like NY might be beyond their capacities and training.

I was stunned by the number of commenters who read the same story as I did, managed to skirt the issues that you pointed out here:

"a family who saw their matriarch's ashes discarded, who ate in dining rooms with dead mice on the floor, who skirted a gauntlet of sexual threats and health crises, and a range of attitudes and actions from jealousy to fights and thefts that were daily stumbling blocks n the way of the consistent confidence needed to grow up, hold a job, and improve the quality of life for children caught in these conflicting currents."

and could only come up with a statement referencing the number of children in the family.

Like many (most?) Americans, I think my life is stressful. But I don't have to think about environmental toxins polluting the air in my home, or deal with the medical issues that plague my children as a result. I don't waste endless amounts of time waiting in line to use a microwave to reheat my kids' dinners, or defy authorities who see my personal microwave and threaten to take it away. I don't live in fear of being sexually harassed or assaulted by the same people who control my family's housing. I'm not awoken at night to the screams of another mother trying to prevent her child's unnecessary death.

No one chooses or wants to live like that.

Many social services and safety nets are guided by the law of negative attraction, the underlying idea that fraud, scams, and ease are the compelling forces for their use. The idea is a host of quick thinking dreamers and schemers better their lives by becoming permanent members of the underclass, without jobs, morality, or impulse control; specialists in receiving services without going anywhere.

That was the take away from many who read the excellent series on Desani and her family, a family who saw their matriarch's ashes discarded, who ate in dining rooms with dead mice on the floor, who skirted a gauntlet of sexual threats and health crises, and a range of attitudes and actions from jealousy to fights and thefts that were daily stumbling blocks n the way of the consistent confidence needed to grow up, hold a job, and improve the quality of life for children caught in these conflicting currents.

Apart from the debate over why and who, in large cities, housing proves to be the most important how: the one least expensive, safest means to shelter a family from negative forces, their own and the ones embedded in the systems intended for their help. Housing security and stability helps organize other parts of the family's lives; their failures more immediately manageable and contained.

The innovative caveat: tie housing to school achievement; the case in Mexico and Brasil, which have received UN recognition for their work in moving families out of poverty.

"..The USA is the last holdout with market-priced medical care not because of any inherent conservative or free market ideology. Rather, as the wealthiest nation that ever existed we are the last ones who can afford it. Switzerland was one of the last advanced economies to abandon market-priced medical care. It is arguably a greater bastion of conservatism than the USA. Switzerland's women were not granted the right to vote until 1971.

The reason that no nation, including the wealthiest can allow markets to set the prices of medical care indefinitely is that demand for medical care is inelastic. Demand for a good or service is inelastic if a percentage increase in price results in a smaller percentage decrease in the quantity demanded. Basic economics tells us that sellers facing inelastic demand will continuously raise prices until prices reach the elastic portion of the demand curve. Consequently in every developed country in the world, all goods or services with inelastic demand have their prices regulated by government. Medical care in the USA being the only exception.

Health care is one of the very few things for which the sellers face inelastic demand. The prices of all other goods and services facing inelastic demand in the USA are regulated by government. Retail electricity service providers face inelastic demand. Consequently, their prices are strictly controlled by all governments worldwide, including the USA...."
http://seekingalpha.com/article/1647632

The demand for medical care in all its forms is highly inelastic, and the the supply side is highly monopolistic. This is a perfect situation for exploitation. It is no wonder that the USA has the most costly health care in the world and still leaves a large proportion of it's citizens without access or very limited access to a standard of care much the rest of the developed world gets. At the same time medicine is becoming more of a science offering knowledge and means as never before that would enable everyone to live healthier and longer lives.

The rhetoric of freedom of choices and free enterprise rings a weird and hollow sound when the results are so contradictory. It is a dangerous trend. I fear the consequences if the slumbering majority wake up too late to effect an orderly change and revolution is the only choice. Bob Edmonton Canada
